S8.T1.caption: Table 1. Prediction performance of compared methods in V-FedMV experiment.

Metric Accuracy(%) Precision(%) Recall(%) F1(%)
V-FedMV 88.76 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.74 90.89 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.83 87.09 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.89 88.93 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.84
Pairwise FL w/o Special 88.30 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.64 89.54 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.68 87.72 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.47 88.61 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.70
Pairwise FL w/o Accel 84.92 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.50 89.00 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.34 81.01 ±plus-or-minus\pm 2.00 84.79±plus-or-minus\pm 0.67
Pairwise FL w/o Alphanum 78.71 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.74 79.63 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.59 79.42 ±plus-or-minus\pm 3.34 79.45±plus-or-minus\pm 1.11
Alphanum w/o FL 84.53 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.68 87.58 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.88 81.81 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.40 84.59 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.75
Accel w/o FL 76.94 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.91 75.51 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.03 82.32 ±plus-or-minus\pm 2.73 78.73 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.13
Special w/o FL 62.30 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.64 70.19 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.81 47.83 ±plus-or-minus\pm 3.09 56.79 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.87
references: Experimental results of V-FedMV and its baselines are shown in Table 1. It is not hard to see that V-FedMV shows the best performance with 88.76% accuracy and 88.93% f1 score. All methods have a low standard deviation, which means all approaches are very stable in the repeated experiments. Meanwhile, we also find the special view makes the most negligible contribution for this task based on the experimental results of Pairwise FL w/o Special and Special w/o FL. Especially, the Pairwise FL w/o Special approach can perform almost the same as V-FedMV. One of the main reasons is that the special view provides less information than the other two views. Besides, we can see that the alphanum view achieves the best accuracy (84.53%) and f1 score (84.59%) among all three views, and the accel view is between the others. While comparing all approaches together, we can easily conclude that the model’s performance increases with more views, demonstrating that the proposed method is effective for multi-view data. Finally, the proposed approach V-FedMV improves 4.23% accuracy, 3.31% precision, 5.28% recall, and 4.34 % f1 score than Alphanum w/o FL that is the best single view learning without FL.

MV w/o FL 87.92 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.51 90.21 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.53 86.15 ±plus-or-minus\pm 2.58 88.09 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.72

Pairwise FL w/o Alphanum 78.77 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.72 79.70 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.60 79.45 ±plus-or-minus\pm 3.17 79.51±plus-or-minus\pm 0.99
Single View FL - Alphanum 84.57 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.65 87.53 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.79 81.97 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.44 84.65 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.73
Single View FL - Accel 76.96 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.91 75.51 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.07 82.39 ±plus-or-minus\pm 2.60 78.77 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.09
Single View FL - Special 62.26 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.58 70.20 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.77 47.65 ±plus-or-minus\pm 3.02 56.67 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.81
references: Table 2 shows the experimental results of H-FedMV and its baselines. It can be observed that H-FedMV outperforms the compared baselines with 88.98% accuracy and 89.17% f1 score. MV w/o FL trains each model locally and the average performance of all local models is worse than H-FedMV. One of the main reason is that federated learning enables H-FedMV to get more training sample information than MV w/o FL, resulting in a better performance. In addition, the significance of each view in model training is similar to the experimental results of H-FedMV and its baselines in last section, i.e., alphanum view ¿ accel view ¿ special view. Eventually, the proposed H-FedMV improves 1.06% accuracy, 0.8% precision, 1.27% recall, and 1.08% f1 score compared to MV w/o FL.

S8.T3.caption: Table 3. Prediction performance of compared methods in S-FedMV
S8.T3.table:
Metric Accuracy(%) Precision(%) Recall(%) F1(%)
S-FedMV 88.90 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.53 89.93 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.82 88.54 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.16 89.22 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.55
Local Sequential H-FedMV 68.31 ±plus-or-minus\pm 5.58 74.77 ±plus-or-minus\pm 5.39 58.10 ±plus-or-minus\pm 9.06 65.24 ±plus-or-minus\pm 7.82
Local Sequential LocalMV 82.27 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.91 84.87 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.50 80.34 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.44 82.44 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.77
Centralized Sequential H-FedMV 88.98 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.52 91.01 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.80 87.42 ±plus-or-minus\pm 1.33 89.17 ±plus-or-minus\pm 0.57
references: Experimental results of different multi-view federated learning methods for sequential data are shown in Table 3. First, we can see that S-FedMV achieves outstanding performance with 88.90% accuracy and 89.22% f1 score. It demonstrates that S-FedMV is the best approach for distributed multi-view sequential data since its performance is close to centralized sequential H-FedMV. Note that centralized sequential H-FedMV is the up-bound performance of all approaches since the feature representation learning can access all training data. Then, we find the results of local sequential H-FedMV can confirm our statement that it is infeasible for each client to preprocess its data independently. It is because the trained models are inconsistent between different clients, and they obtained a bad representation learning of H-FedMV. We can also see that the proposed approach S-FedMV is better than local sequential LocalMV, which trains the local model on local sequential data only.
